TopicTitle: Paper Space Program 1.8 (KSP Rocket Parts papercraft)

Articles.Content:
Dunno, does it? Got the center of lift from ksp and measured the center of mass irl:

http://i.imgur.com/tityp1N.jpg

I figure the com is a bit too far ahead since there is no fuel in the back. And those aren't real wings at all, just plates XD. On the other hand if you define flying as flipping through the air, then yes of course.

I nearly did that model rocket thing last new year (had an idea to stick a firework inside a srb) but didn't end up having enough time and the safety was questionable at best lol.

Plates are wings. It's just that the wings have a neutral Angle of Attack relative to the fuselage. You point it slightly up from prograde and hey presto! Plate becomes a wing. The same thing happens with structural plates in KSP, which can be used as wings.

http://i.imgur.com/vqWUYaf.png

So this is about the design I decided to use, gonna start compiling the parts and printing today.

That will look great, MoffKalast. I specially want to see how the KR-2L will look like. Also, are you planning on making the stages separable?

Plates are wings. It's just that the wings have a neutral Angle of Attack relative to the fuselage. You point it slightly up from prograde and hey presto! Plate becomes a wing. The same thing happens with structural plates in KSP, which can be used as wings.

Well yeah, but I meant wings as in things that are shaped in a way that creates a high pressure below it and low above it (aka squashed teardrop shape).

That will look great, MoffKalast. I specially want to see how the KR-2L will look like. Also, are you planning on making the stages separable?

Yep, indeed I am, the boosters from the first stage, the command module from the first stage and the escape tower from the command module.

I didn't really start working on it yet, had a little change of plans and made a model of a ship from my game first, which took me these last two days. I'm getting around to it anytime now.
Managed to construct new landing gears by pieces

Phew , finally released all the new parts

On 6/29/2016 at 11:37 PM, Ultimate Steve said:

You might have used a tad bit too much of duck tape.

Seriously though, I'd recommend using any type of glue over duck tape when making models if you have the option.

This is just awesome . I have always wanted to make one of my KSP crafts out of paper.

It's going to be a bit of a challenge tough, to create one of my planes out of paper cause:

1. the pack doesn't include all the newest parts.

2. recreating piles of clipped/rotated parts would be a total nightmare.

But, i do have one aircraft that is possible to make, and it's an old one. It's the Fouglas FC-8, my oldest SCA aircraft and the first commercial aircraft i made after the new MK-3 parts by @Porkjet arrived.

And yes, it has survived to this day, and still works, tough it has been updated by quite a bit.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=362949279

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=362948569

Those are links to the original version. The orbiter riding on top, that is the other survivor from those days.

And below are picks of the new version.

I believe, that after its built, it will be the biggest papermodel i've ever made (i have built dozens of papermodels before), even bigger than the mighty B-36 Piecemaker model from Fiddlers Green.

It will propably be about 5 A-4's in length (about 1 meter) and about the same in width. But i like making big papermodels, rather than tiny little postcard sized micromodels.

I plan on making it as close to the original as possible. That means, that im going to make new version of the static landing gears that i had on the original, that where built using a lot of struts and ruggedized wheels, with some hidden landing gears to make it all work.

This time i might make them out of I-beams tough.

And to save space, it's going to have removable main wings and elevators.

 

 

I might end up making the orbiter as well, but i'm not sure. I would be more keen on making a fighter jet of some kind, or maby a MK-2 SSTO.

Again, if im going to build something out of those parts, it basically can't have any clipped or rotated parts, or otherwise its going to make it really difficult to make all those part fit correctly. But it would be doable.

 

If i can make a suggestion, i would absolutely love to see the prop engines from @keptin KAX pack getting turned into papermodels. Or even some of the prop engines from @Lack SXT pack.

 

Anyway. Keep up the good work .

2 hours ago, MoffKalast said:

You might have used a tad bit too much of duck tape.

Might.

Seriously though, I'd recommend using any type of glue over duck tape when making models if you have the option.

 

After a bit of practice, you can get pretty good results using crystal tape.

Here's is one example.

It's a model of the Airforce One from Paper-Replika, made using crystal tape and scissors and nothing else. Well, it does have a couple cocktail sticks in there to keep the wings straight.

It was made in one day. And that is the main reason i use tape over glue. I don't have to spend hours waiting for glue to dry, and i don't have spend hours cutting all the tiny glue tabs, i can instead jut ignore them. it speeds up the process by a ton, leaving me time for other things while still producing good results.

 

But, Making micromodels and other models with really tiny details, is a bit difficult. but not impossible.

 

I do use hot glue for attaching some parts: like wheels, antennas and gunbarrels tough.

Because those things just won't stay on/straight when using tape, it also looks pretty horrid in some cases.
